overview.title: Secure, Private, and Useful Ubiquitous Sensing
overview.subtitle: Building Privacy-Preserving IoT Programming Frameworks
overview.abstract: With the explosion of IoT sensors deployed across our environment, we are investigating how to expose useful programming abstractions to developers while ensuring secure and private cyber-physical information flow. This NSF CAREER project focuses on developing novel frameworks that balance utility with privacy guarantees in ubiquitous sensing scenarios.

objectives.title: Privacy-Preserving Data Collection
objectives.description: Develop mechanisms for collecting sensor data while preserving user privacy through differential privacy and secure computation techniques.

objectives.title: Programming Abstractions
objectives.description: Create intuitive APIs and frameworks that allow developers to build IoT applications without compromising security.

objectives.title: Information Flow Control
objectives.description: Implement systems to track and control how sensitive information flows through distributed IoT networks.

sections.title: Theoretical Foundations
sections.content: We are developing formal models for privacy-preserving information flow in distributed sensing systems. Our approach combines concepts from differential privacy, information theory, and type systems to create provable guarantees about data protection.

sections.title: System Design
sections.content: The project involves building a complete software stack from low-level sensor abstractions to high-level programming interfaces. We focus on creating composable primitives that maintain privacy properties across system boundaries.

sections.title: Experimental Validation
sections.content: We validate our approaches through both simulation studies and real-world deployments in smart building environments, measuring both privacy guarantees and system performance.
